t: Job 40
And*p the Lord*s said to Job:
“Shall*pn a faultfinder contend with the Almighty? He*ld who argues with God, let him answer it.”
Job Promises Silence
Then*p Job answered the Lord*s and said:
“Behold,*pn I am of small account; what shall I answer you? I*ld lay my hand on my mouth.
I*ln have spoken once, and I will not answer; twice,*ld but I will proceed no further.”
The Lord Challenges Job
Then*p the Lord*s answered Job out of the whirlwind and said:
“Dress*pn for action like a man; I*ld will question you, and you make it known to me.
Will*ln you even put me in the wrong? Will*ld you condemn me that you may be in the right?
Have*ln you an arm like God, and*ld can you thunder with a voice like his?
“Adorn*pn yourself with majesty and dignity; clothe*ld yourself with glory and splendor.
Pour*ln out the overflowings of your anger, and*ld look on everyone who is proud and abase him.
Look*ln on everyone who is proud and bring him low and*ld tread down the wicked where they stand.
Hide*ln them all in the dust together; bind*ld their faces in the world below.
Then*ln will I also acknowledge to you that*ld your own right hand can save you.
“Behold,*pn Behemoth, which*ld I made as I made you; he*ld eats grass like an ox.
Behold,*ln his strength in his loins, and*ld his power in the muscles of his belly.
He*ln makes his tail stiff like a cedar; the*ld sinews of his thighs are knit together.
His*ln bones are tubes of bronze, his*ld limbs like bars of iron.
“He*pn is the first of the works of God; let*ld him who made him bring near his sword!
For*ln the mountains yield food for him where*ld all the wild beasts play.
Under*ln the lotus plants he lies, in*ld the shelter of the reeds and in the marsh.
For*ln his shade the lotus trees cover him; the*ld willows of the brook surround him.
Behold,*ln if the river is turbulent he is not frightened; he*ld is confident though Jordan rushes against his mouth.
Can*ln one take him by his eyes, or*ld pierce his nose with a snare?
